answers.answer: DEAR ADELE -Thanks for your questions.  I would encourage you to go back to your doctor and let him or her know that you are still not feeling well.  At the very least a thorough physical exam as well as a few laboratory tests might identify a treatable condiiton  - or, if normal, reassure you that your body is o.k.Numbness is a vague sympton - and without seeing you myself - I really cannot make a diagnosis. But, again  - a thorough exam, some laboratory tests (including tests for iron, sugar), and even an Xray or CAT scan might be considered as part of your workup.  Also - a careful diet history might be useful - i.e., are you eating healthy and on a regular basis?  At the very least - treating an anemia, if still present, might make you feel better. But DO seek medical attention if the numbness persists.Your doctor might want you to see a Neurologist - to be thorough.Good luck - Dr. Vinton.
are you diabetic? did they test for diabeties i know being thirsty is a sympton of diabeties
Thank you for reading and responding to my problem, however, I don't have diabetes (at least I don't think I do).  You said that I did and I was wondering if this is a possibility?  Thanks.  Adelle

question: I'm an 18 year old college sophmore.  I've been trying for days to post my question in the neurology section, however I have been unsuccessful.  I am sorry to bother you outside of your specialty. The problem is that both of my little toes have gone numb constantly for the last three days.  I went to my health center and they knew about as much about this problem as I do...nothing.  I am over-weight, 5'5", white, female.  I am really concerned about this problem.  I have some other symptoms but I don't know if they are related or not.  I am always thirsty, I'm anemic, and I get dizzy really easily.  Thanks for taking the time to read this and I appologize again for applying my question to the wrong doctors.  If you can forward this to someone with more information, I would appreciate it.  Adelle
title: numbness
